Slightly strange article, in that it, in essence, it merely backs up what Orwell himself says about Homage, which that it is a partial account of what Orwell himself saw.
The last paragraph containing this "Instructions left before his death for a later edition ignored his acceptance of the need for a unified war effort in Spain. It is as if the Orwell of Animal Farm, Nineteen Eighty-Four and the lister of suspect fellow-travellers for the Foreign Office thought that he should let it stand as another nail in the communist coffin, despite its distortion of the Spanish situation." doesn't actually seem to make sense either - why is it Orwell's fault that his notes were ignored?

I'm struggling to put into words about this.
Absolutely gutted. When I first started semi-regularly visiting Vicarage Road in the early 90s, it was a shell of a football club. Floating around in the lower reaches of the (now) championship, falling to bits, neglected.
His return saw a huge jump in gates, and belief returning. He didn't save us from relegation, immediately, but he worked in the background.
Got Elton back involved. Put on his tracksuit, and got Watford - little old Watford! - back in the Premier League. A day at Wembley, with a team of cheap buys. Beating Liverpool. Taking Utd to the wire at Vicarage Road. A team we could all believe in.
Before his arrival in the late 70s, we'd spent two years in the top two tiers. Since then, we've only spent two years outside them.
He transformed the club. Gave the town a team to be proud of.
He's one of my all time heroes.
Vale, GT.

I think this seasons Champions Cup is showing that there's a fag paper between the rest of the leagues in Europe. The French might have the budgets, but the Irish have some really good players, well coached that play with the passion that comes from having a level of attachment to your team that some of the French teams lack, certainly away from home. AP teams kind of fall somewhere in the middle, I think.
That said, the worst team(s) in the Pro 12 seem to be much worse than the worst AP teams.

I've not seen the Crown, but it's hard to see him as a particularly sympathetic character; it's worth bearing in mind he was sympathetic to the Nazis, was apparently lined up to become monarch once more if Hitler had invaded (although I'm not 100% on the accuracy of this)
His softness on Nazism also means that you can certainly have fun with a counter history where he didn't abdicate, and his influence led to Britain either staying out of the war entirely, or seeing Halifax rather than Churchill taking the Prime Ministership in 1940, leaving Europe to the Germans.
But that's probably a story for another thread
Camilla isn't a Princess / pedant. She's the Duchess of Cornwall, and IF Charles assumes the throne, will assume the title of Consort, iirc.
